In our optimization, we have three weight parameters w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1}, w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}, and ÏğœŒ\rho, where w1+w2=1subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤21w_{1}+w_{2}=1 as explained above. If w1>w2subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2w_{1}>w_{2}, energy consumption will take a more dominant position in our optimization problem. If w2>w1subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ‘¤1w_{2}>w_{1}, it is more important to optimize the delay instead of energy.
Analogously, if the weight parameter ÏğœŒ\rho is larger, the model accuracy will take a more dominant position. To explore the effect of weight parameters of total energy and time consumption and model accuracy separately, we first show experiments under different (w1,w2)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2(w_{1},w_{2}) with fixed ÏğœŒ\rho and then show results under different ÏğœŒ\rho with fixed (w1,w2)=(0.5,0.5)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤20.50.5(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.5,0.5). The algorithms to be compared with are summarized in Table I (comparison with other work is in SectionÂ VII-D).

In this paper, we formulate a joint optimization of energy, completion time and model accuracy problem in FL via Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA). FDMA means the spectral resources are divided among MAR devices. Each device is assigned a unique frequency band, which is dedicated to that user for the communication duration. The objective function is a weighted combination of total energy, time, and model accuracy. Total energy consumption, total completion time and model accuracy model are discussed in SectionsÂ III-A,Â III-B andÂ III-C, respectively.
Notations in this paper are listed in TableÂ II in Appendix A. Bold symbols stand for vectors.
